coredata.dc:title: A new method for picosecond time-resolved infrared spectroscopy: applications to CO photodissociation from iron porphyrins
coredata.dc:creator: Moore, J.N.
Hansen, P.A.
Hochstrasser, R.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A new method for obtaining picosecond infrared spectra and kinetics is presented. It incorporates a tunable infrared diode laser in conjunction with two cavity-dumped dye lasers synchronously pumped by a mode-locked and Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. New results are obtained for the photodissociation of hemin and myoglobin carbonyls and for their geometric structures by means of IR-optical polarization measurements.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 138, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 A NEW METHOD FOR PICOSECOND TIME-RESOLVED INFRARED SPECTROSCOPY: APPLICATIONS TO CO PHOTODISSOCIATION FROM IRON PORPHYRINS * J.N. MOORE, P.A. HANSEN and R.M. HOCHSTRASSER Department of Chemistry, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6323, USA Received 28 May 1987 A rew method for obtaining picosecond infrared spectra and kinetics is presented. It incorporates a tunable infrared diode laser in conjunction with two cavity-dumped dye lasers synchronously pumped by a mode-locked and g-switched Nd:YAG laser. New results are obtained for the photodissociation of hemin and myoglobin carbonyls and for their geometric structures by means of IR-optical polarization measurements. 1. Introduction Vibrational spectroscopy, in particular infrared spectroscopy, provides reliable fingerprints of molecular structure. It is therefore important to develop techniques for vibrational spectroscopic studies aimed at determining structural features of transient species and considerable effort has already been made in this regard [ 1 ]. The study of short-lived transient species in condensed phases requires that picosecond infrared spectroscopic methods be devel- oped. Progress toward a tunable picosecond IR methodology was made by Kaiser and co-workers recently [2]. They obtained the IR pulses by means of a LiNb03 parametric generator or by down-con- version of intense pulses from a Nd: YAG laser. Other picosecond IR transient studies in condensed matter have involved IR-optical resonances detected by fluorescence [ 3 ], tunable IR absorption detected by anti-Stokes Raman scattering [4], and by ground state recovery [ 5 ] with the IR originating from opti- cal parametric amplifiers pumped by intense low- repetition-rate pulses in each case. The time evolu- tion of the vibrational coherence induced by intense IR pulses was also studied recently [6]. Of these approaches only that of ref. [2] was applied in a pump-probe experiment involving transient species. There is clearly a great need for a continuously tun- * This research was supported by grants from NSF and NIH. 110 able, high-sensitivity, high-repetition-rate picosec- ond IR technique. We report here such a new and adaptable method for the study of infrared spectra of transient species with picosecond time resolution. The technique is established through studies of the photodissociation and the structure of the carbon monoxide complexes of hemin and myoglobin (MbCO). The photodis- sociation processes have been studied previously by observations of visible absorption spectral transients in the picosecond [7,8] and subpicosecond [9] regime. Nanosecond transients were also studied for hemin-CO [10]. The present work is the first in which optically induced changes are directly observed through picosecond studies of the infrared spectrum of the photolyzed solutions at ambient temperatures. 2. Experimental method The experiment (see fig. 1) uses two visible dye lasers, each synchronously pumped by the fre- quency-doubled output of a mode-locked and Q- switched cw Nd:YAG oscillator. The dye lasers are each cavity dumped at 700 Hz. One of the dye la- sers (DL2, wavelength 558 nm) is used to photolyze the sample. The output of a cw lead salt diode laser (Spectra Physics, Laser Analytics Division) passes through the sample collinear with DL2. The average IR power is w 5 mW while that of DL2 is w 5 mW 0 009-2614/87/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 138, number CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 ML OS ND-YAG DIODE LASER SHG \ Ul,, 1DYE LASER 2 PUMP \ DELAY LINE DYE LASER 1 UC CRYSTALC] \ SAMPLE 0),, 3. Results and discussion The sample ofMbCO, prepared as described below, was contained in a variable thickness flow cell hav- ing CaFz windows. The diode laser was tunable in the range 1990-1920 cm"'. The unphotolyzed sam- ple showed 45% transmission at the peak of the car- bonyl absorption region at 1949 cm"', with 57% transmission due to solvent alone. Thus an increase in transmission of 12% could be expected if the bound carbonyl absorption were completely removed by the photodissociation. Fig. 2a shows the spectrum obtained by scanning the diode laser at a time setting of 150 ps after photolysis. The well-known [11] car- Fig. 1. Picosecond time-resolved infrared spectrometer. with 25 ps pulses. A modulation is introduced into the IR beam by the changes in transmission of the sample induced by the pump pulse. The transmitted IR beam is then combined with the fixed frequency output ofDLl (wavelength 562 nm) and both beams are directed collinearly into a LiI03 crystal which is angle tuned to generate light at the sum of the fre- quencies of DL1 and the modulated IR beam. The upconverted signal is detected by a photomultiplier after being separated from the DL1 beam in a double monochromator. The average power of DL1 was w 1 mW. The transmission changes in the cw IR beam were sampled by scanning the delay between DL1 and DL2 at a fixed IR frequency. The IR spectrum could be obtained by scanning the diode laser fre- quency at a fixed delay with the spectral resolution being limited by the bandwidth of DL1 (5 cm"', fwhm). The observed signal is linear in the inten- sities of DL1, DL2 and the IR laser beams. The time resolution was w 10 ps. The experimental arrangement permits measure- ments ofanisotropic IR-optical absorption. The ver- tically and horizontally polarized components of the transmitted IR beam were sampled separately by rotating both the LiI03 crystal and a )J1 plate in the DL1 beam by 90 . In this way we could measure the IR absorption for both parallel (T|| ) and perpendic- ularly (/J_ ) polarized pump and probe beams on a timescale where there can be little overall movement of the sample molecules. 1970 1950 1930 DIODE LASER WAVENUMBER (cm-) -200 -100 0 100 TIME DELAY (ps) Fig. 2. (Top) Time-resolved infrared spectrum ofMbCO taken at a time delay of 150 ps between the pump and probe dye lasers. Positive A (absorbance) corresponds to an increase in infrared transmission. The error bar indicates the spread of data points around the plotted line. (Bottom) Infrared transmission as a function of time delay, monitored at the peak of the bound CO stretch ofMbCO at w 1949 cm"'. The rise was indistinguishable from a two-dye-laser pump-probe bleaching curve ofrhodamine 640. Ill Volume 138, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 bonyl absorption of MbCO is significantly dimin- ished by pumping with the visible laser. Note that the spectral resolution is just sufficient to resolve the 1950 cm-1 group of lines into its components. The time dependence of the transmission at 1949 cm"1 is shown in fig. 2b. This result clearly shows that the bound CO absorption disappears rapidly compared with the time resolution of the experiment of 10 ps. The results for hemin-CO in glycerol-water are shown in figs. 3a and 3b. In this case the CO is also dissociated in less than 10 ps but the bound CO absorption recovers on the experimental timescale. An initial recovery of 25% of the dissociated mol- ecules occurs with a time constant of 60 ps; this is followed by a much slower recovery extending beyond the 600 ps scans of the present experiment. Values of/J.//n were measured near (=0 (i.e. cor- 1980 1960 1940 DIODE LASER WAVENUMBER (cm"1) 0 200 400 600 TIME DELAY (ps) Fig. 3. (Top) Time-resolved infrared spectrum of hemin-CO taken at a time delay of 50 ps between the pump and probe dye lasers. (Bottom) Change in infrared absorbance as a function of time delay, monitored at the peak of the bound CO stretch of hemin-CO at ss I960 cm-'. responding to the time when the peak pumping intensity is present at the sample). For MbCO we found 7^//ii =0.89 0.23, while for hemin-CO this ratio was considerably larger at IJI\\= 1.43 0.45. These measurements were carried out at the lowest possible pump energy to avoid saturation effects on the polarization ratio. Sperm whale Mb (Sigma) was dissolved in phos- phate buffer at pH 7, and bovine hemin in 60% (v/v) glycerol/NaOH, NaCI buffer at pH 11. Both samples were stirred under a CO atmosphere for several hours, reduced with sodium dithionite, and further stirred under CO for several hours to form the car- boxy derivatives. The final concentrations were w 15 and 6 mM for MbCO and hemin-CO, respectively. The observed kinetic behavior of MbCO following photolysis is entirely consistent with earlier picosec- ond and subpicosecond studies that monitored the optical absorption spectrum [7-9]. The CO is dis- sociated in less than 10 ps according to our experi- ment in which the bound carbonyl absorption is studied. The free carbon monoxide absorbs at a dif- ferent frequency (w 1130 cm"') and has only about 10% of the absorption coefficient of the bound form in the infrared [ 12]: It is not detected in the present experiment. No evidence of any subpicosecond recombination of CO was observed. In the case of the protoheme the photodissociation also occurred rapidly compared with our time res- olution, consistent with deductions made from stud- ies of the optical transient spectra [ 10]. In this case, however, there was evidence of geminate recombi- nations of the photodissociated CO to the parent heme. Fig. 3b clearly shows two geminate recombi- nation phases. The first is evidenced by the rapid (w60 ps) recovery of 25% of the bound carbonyl absorption. This is followed by a much slower recov- ery of the bound system. Previous studies of pro- toheme-CO recombination in glycerol/HaO solutions having high viscosity [10] have involved nanosec- ond excitation pulses. The recombination rate con- stant was deduced to be 3x 109 s-' on the basis of measurements of the recombination yield versus vis- cosity. One interpretation of our results is that the solution contains at least two types of protoheme sol- vent configurations; one in which the dissociated CO cannot easily escape into the solvent and another in which the escape is facile and the subsequent dif- 112 Volume 138 number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 fusive recombination is relatively slow. In reality there may be a range of such configurations. At the present signal-to-noise we cannot say whether or not the initial decay is exponential, but it is quite dis- tinct from the slower (of nanosecond order) recom- bination and hence a continuous distribution of subnanosecond recombination rates is ruled out. It is possible that the rapid phase arises because of local heating of the solvent resulting in a lowering of the viscosity. It is significant that photodissociated MbCO shows no substantial subnanosecond recombination. This was also noted from studies of the optical spectrum [13,14]. These results for the protein are in marked contrast to those of the protoheme. They suggest that after photodissociation the displacements of the sidechains forming the interior of the heme pocket, evident from recent X-ray diffraction studies [15], must restrict the recombination of CO. In effect, this structural relaxation creates a significant steric bar- rier to rebinding. The anisotropic absorption of heme systems is particularly straightforward to interpret because the heme behaves to high accuracy as a circular oscil- lator [16,17]. This implies that the probability dis- tribution of optically excited hemes depends only on one angle: the distribution is sin2^, where 6 is the angle between the heme normal and the electric vec- tor of the absorbing radiation. The IR absorption of the CO-stretching motion is assumed to be polarized along the CO bond axis. Thus, if the angle between the CO bond and the normal to the heme plane is a, it is easy to show that a=sin-l[(2-7^)/(0.5+/^)]l/2 , (1) where R=IJI^. It is assumed that the measure- ments of /ii and JJ. are made while the molecules in the sample are fixed in the laboratory frame. This is certainly valid for the protein in HzO and for the model heme in the high-viscosity solvents used here. For MbCO we have measured R= 0.89 0.23, which implies that the most probable value of a is 63 (48<a<90 ). In crystalline MbCO the Fe-C-0 angle is reported [15] to be restricted to the range 120-150 , corresponding to values of a between 30 and 60 . In the crystal there are also a range of angles made by the projection of the C-0 axis onto the heme plane, but our experiment is not dependent on these azimuthal angles as long as the heme TI-electron tran- sitions involve any two orthogonal directions in the heme plane. Clearly our measurement is consistent with the X-ray diffraction results and we can say that the Fe-C-0 bond is significantly bent also for MbCO in solution. In recent EXAFS measurements on solu- tions of MbCO, Powers et al. [18] have reported a value of 127 (a =53 ) for the Fe-C-0 angle. It should be noted that our measurement does not dis- tinguish between a bent Fe-C-0 bond and a linear (or less bent) Fe-C-0 bond that is tilted to the heme plane. The X-ray diffraction results are also unable to conclude with certainty on this point. The polarization for the model heme-CO mole- cule gives (from eq. (1)) the significantly different value of a = 33 (13 < a < 56 ). Even with the large uncertainty we see that the Fe-C-0 is significantly more upright in the case of the model heme-CO in glycerol/water. Crystal structures of model heme-CO complexes have shown that Fe-C-0 is linear and perpendicular to the heme plane [19]. Our observed value is significantly different from R = 2, expected for a perfectly perpendicular structure. Saturation effects could have reduced the observed value by only w 5%. We therefore suggest that the solvent cage is responsible for forcing the Fe-C-0 bond to bend by w 30 from linear. The difference between the model compounds and the hemeprotein was suggested [15] to arise from constraints on the CO location from the residues that compose the interior of the heme pocket. Presumably, our results indicate that these changes in the heme pocket resulting from the inter- actions with CO are present to some extent also in the solution phase protein. The results clearly demonstrate that the apparatus has great potential for the measurement of picosec- ond transient infrared kinetics and spectroscopy. The spectra shown in figs. 2a and 3a have nearly trans- form-limited spectral resolution though small improvements are still possible in the pump pulse quality. The method was tested with a number of diodes at 1900 cm"' and higher energy that could be upconverted in LiI03, but other materials such as sil- ver thiogallate will readily permit upconversion in the lower frequency, fingerprint region. The peak visible power on the crystal was less than 10 MW/cm2. The dye lasers used in this type of exper- iment can readily be replaced by any sources having 113 Volume 138, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 average power in the 5 mW range and peak power in the gating crystal less than 100 MW/cm2 (e.g. one dye laser or even a laser oscillator alone could be employed). This signal condition is readily achieved by picosecond or subpicosecond dye lasers of many types so that there would appear to be no funda- mental difficulty in obtaining such time resolution in the IR spectrum. References [ 1 ] A. Laubereau and M. Stockburger, eds.. Proceedings in physics. Vol. 4. Time resolved vibrational spectroscopy (Springer, Berlin, 1985). [2] T. Elsaesser and W. Kaiser, Chem. Phys. head.ce:title: A new method for picosecond time-resolved infrared spectroscopy: applications to CO photodissociation from iron porphyrins

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6323, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A new method for obtaining picosecond infrared spectra and kinetics is presented. It incorporates a tunable infrared diode laser in conjunction with two cavity-dumped dye lasers synchronously pumped by a mode-locked and Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. New results are obtained for the photodissociation of hemin and myoglobin carbonyls and for their geometric structures by means of IR-optical polarization measurements.
